stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on the level design and asset creation for Course 14, a world made of craft supplies. The main activities included brainstorming platforming elements, fighting against a linear level layout by drawing player paths in Blender, creating a mushroom platform from a toilet paper roll, and diagnosing performance issues on N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively designing against linearity in Course 14, using a grease pencil in Blender to map out multiple, branching paths to ensure the level feels open, similar to 'Peaches Fury'.
development_findings.quote: I don't like this. This is all too linear and obvious. It should be a path from here to go like over there or something.

development_findings.summary: Kaze made significant low-level performance optimizations, saving 30 CPU instructions in the graphics renderer by caching a value in a loop and applying other micro-optimizations.
development_findings.quote: I found 30 instruction improvement in Graph Render again. Which is also fucking sick. Mostly from caching the GMAT stack index.

development_findings.summary: While testing on N64 hardware, Kaze diagnosed that the level's performance issues are caused by RDP overdraw (too many overlapping transparent surfaces), not an excessive polygon count, giving him a clear path for optimization.
development_findings.quote: The RSP could run this at like 50 FPS and the RDP is at 36.8. That means it's all the overdraw. So we used around half of our polygon budget for the level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze designed a new platforming element: a mushroom made from a gift-wrapped toilet paper roll. The creative process involved finding inspiration, modeling, texturing, and debating small details like adding a 3D staple to enhance the crafted aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: Dude, the toilet paper roll is too good. I can't not do this. But I'm just not sure on the stapler needle. Is the stapler needle too much?

development_findings.summary: The level's theme is a 'cardboard diorama' built from various craft supplies like crayons, rulers, cardboard fences, toilet paper rolls, and paper feathers.
Kaze plans to release a 'somewhat public' demo soon, which will only feature the game's first course.
development_findings.quote: I'm gonna release a demo soon and it will be somewhat public. But it will just be course one.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is struggling to fill large, flat, empty cardboard surfaces and is exploring ideas like stacking cardboard to create mountains or adding more papercraft decorations to make them more engaging.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's core design philosophy for the craft level is that materials must look and behave realistically to be convincing to the player, dictating details like shaders for gift wrap.
context_findings.quote: This is what I meant with the materials need to look realistic to be convincing. Cause we all know wrap paper has a little bit of a shine to it. So if it doesn't have to shine, people might not identify it as a wrap paper.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strict personal rule to not reference games or media that were released after Super Mario 64, maintaining a period-appropriate feel.
context_findings.quote: You know lava came on after my 64 things it was lifetime. So no reference to that. That's my rule.

context_findings.summary: Kaze clarified he is self-employed and mentioned a specific client issue where he is owed $3,500 but cannot issue an invoice due to missing address information needed for sales tax calculation.
context_findings.quote: I miss paychecks, but what? Damn that really sucks out there. I sent me like around $3,500 at this point, but I can't write an invoice to him because he didn't give me like his address.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a personal anecdote about enjoying his new automatic lawnmower, humorously referring to himself as a 'boomer'.
context_findings.quote: I have become a boomer by the way. I installed an automatic lawnmower and I enjoy my lawnmower right now. That's fucked up isn't it?

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering creating more mainstream, 'normie' content for his YouTube channel, such as explaining the BLJ, because it would be easy to produce and likely perform well.

key_stories.title: Crafting the Perfect Platform
key_stories.summary: To create a new platform, Kaze went through a detailed creative process from concept to execution. He settled on a mushroom made from a toilet paper roll and gift wrap, spending significant time perfecting the textures and shaders to make the craft materials look realistic and convincing.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed a new platforming element for the craft-themed level that was visually interesting, thematically appropriate, and respected the N64's technical limitations.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed ideas with his chat, researched 'paper mushrooms' online for inspiration, and found an image that sparked the toilet paper roll concept. He then modeled the object, debated the inclusion of a staple for authenticity, sourced and modified a texture for the roll, and coded a custom shader for the shiny top.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully designed and implemented a mushroom platform made from a toilet paper roll, gift wrap, and a staple. He created a custom shader to give the gift wrap a realistic shine, fulfilling his principle that materials must look convincing.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, the toilet paper roll is too good. I can't not do this.

key_stories.title: The Fight Against Linearity
key_stories.summary: Faced with a level that felt too linear, Kaze developed a method of drawing player paths in Blender to visualize gameplay flow. This process helped him break the linearity, create multiple interesting routes, and rebalance the entire level layout by moving the starting point.
key_stories.challenge: The initial layout for Course 14 felt too linear and simple, with paths that went straight forward without interesting choices.
key_stories.process: Kaze used Blender's grease pencil tool to visually draw the intended player paths directly onto the 3D model. This allowed him to analyze the flow of the level, identify linear sections, and add new routes to create a more open-ended experience.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze established a non-linear layout with multiple, interconnected paths leading to various objectives. This new layout prompted him to move the spawn point to a more central, balanced location.
key_stories.key_quote: So what I'm doing right here is trying to draw the paths that you can take throughout the level. So we can have an idea of what this level will play like.

key_stories.title: Hunting the Performance Bottleneck
key_stories.summary: When the level ran poorly on an N64, Kaze used a hardware debugger to diagnose the problem. He discovered the lag was caused by rendering too many overlapping pixels (overdraw), not by too many polygons, allowing him to focus his optimization efforts on fixing the correct issue.
key_stories.challenge: The level was experiencing performance issues when running on original N64 hardware, and Kaze needed to identify the specific cause to fix it.
key_stories.process: Kaze loaded the level onto an N64 via his Summer Cart. By analyzing the debug output, he compared the processing times of the Reality Signal Processor (RSP, for geometry) and the Reality Display Processor (RDP, for pixel rendering). The high RDP time clearly indicated an overdraw problem.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze determined the bottleneck was the RDP struggling with overdraw from many transparent or layered surfaces, not the RSP being overloaded with polygons. This gave him a clear optimization target: find and remove unnecessary overlapping geometry without sacrificing visual quality.
key_stories.key_quote: The RSP could run this at like 50 FPS and the RDP is at 36.8. That means it's all the overdraw.
